body: Thanks for reporting! I'm wondering if we should instead introduce a `List<Class<?>> getSupportedTypes()` method in case we want to support some hypothetical other type in the future. Thoughts?

My first feeling about `List<Class<?>> getSupportedTypes()` was that it leaves too much space to the factory, but that's probably not a problem since JUnit would only do `contains` checks on the returned list/set based on the target type.

Do you imagine to always return `Arrays.asList(Path.class, File.class)` (or equivalent) in the default method, and let it evolve whenever JUnit adds more supported types?

One more alternative could be something similar to [`canSupport(Class<?>, Class<?>)`](https://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/core/convert/ConversionService.html#canConvert(java.lang.Class,java.lang.Class)) of the Spring `ConversionService`, e.g., `supports(Class<?>)`. In this case, the default method would just return `true`.

I'm wondering if we could check the file system of the returned `Path` and throw an exception when it's not the default file system and trying to inject a `File`. Can you imagine a case where that wouldn't be sufficient?

> Can you imagine a case where that wouldn't be sufficient?

No, not really ‚Äì this approach seems sensible to me! Plus, it's the easiest to adjust if new corner cases arise.

I can start with the implementation unless you see something else that needs to be defined.
No, I think we're good to go! üëç

rename.from: Improve user experience if `@TempDir` factory does not support `File` annotated elements
rename.to: `@TempDir` should fail fast with `File` annotated elements if temp directory file system is not default

rename.from: `@TempDir` should fail fast with `File` annotated elements if temp directory file system is not default
rename.to: `@TempDir` with `File` annotated elements should fail fast if temp directory file system is not default

body:
@marcphilipp I'm struggling with deciding where the responsibility of checking the file system should be implemented:

* In the `getPathOrFile` method:

  https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/b105747923df9d9a85b4426b4cc5e11c4692ff8d/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/extension/TempDirectory.java#L250-L261

  **Pros**
  * No new parameter needs to be propagated to the `CloseablePath` constructor

  **Cons**
  * The `CloseablePath` instance should be closed in case the file system validation fails
  * Testing to be covered in both `TempDirectoryPerDeclarationTests` and `TempDirectoryPerContextTests`

* In the `CloseablePath` constructor validation:

  https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/b105747923df9d9a85b4426b4cc5e11c4692ff8d/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/extension/TempDirectory.java#L287-L298

  **Pros**
  * No `CloseablePath` instance is created when a non-default file system is used
  * Testing can be added to `CloseablePathTests`, although with a bit of complexity (e.g., test case matrix via dynamic tests)

  **Cons**
  * A `Class<?> type` parameter needs to be propagated down to the `CloseablePath` constructor

At the moment, I tend to favor the new constructor parameter, but I wanted to have another opinion before going forward.

I think the validation should occur _before_ creating the temporary directory, if possible. Additionally, we need to ensure whenever `TempDirFactory.createTempDirectory` was called,  the corresponding `CloseablePath` is closed so the cleanup is executed. Therefore, I think we should not throw an exception from the `CloseablePath` constructor but validate in the `getPathOrFile` method.

> I think the validation should occur before creating the temporary directory, if possible.

Theoretically, the directory is created as soon as `TempDirFactory.createTempDirectory` returns. To perform the validation before the directory is created, we'd have to introduce some new API for `TempDirFactory` (related to https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/3910#issuecomment-2260559403). Or do you have something else in mind?

> Additionally, we need to ensure whenever `TempDirFactory.createTempDirectory` was called, the corresponding `CloseablePath` is closed so the cleanup is executed.

Indeed, that's already a gap caused by #3901, which I addressed separately in #3911.

> Therefore, I think we should not throw an exception from the `CloseablePath` constructor but validate in the `getPathOrFile` method.

If the `CloseablePath` constructor throws an exception, it would be handled similarly to #3911, i.e., with a try/catch that ensures the underlying factory is also closed in case a `PreconditionViolationException` is thrown by the temp directory validation. This way, no `CloseablePath` instance would be created, and no close handling would need to be in the `getPathOrFile` caller.

Of course, we can push this logic up to `getPathOrFile` and that will require explicit closure of the `CloseablePath`, as you mentioned.

I think both directions can work so happy to follow your preference. I just wanted to bring both options to the table üôÇ

> > I think the validation should occur before creating the temporary directory, if possible.
> 
> Theoretically, the directory is created as soon as `TempDirFactory.createTempDirectory` returns. To perform the validation before the directory is created, we'd have to introduce some new API for `TempDirFactory` (related to [#3910 (comment)](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/3910#issuecomment-2260559403)). Or do you have something else in mind?

You're right. Let's not introduce a new API at this time.

> Indeed, that's already a gap caused by #3901, which I addressed separately in #3911.
> 
> > Therefore, I think we should not throw an exception from the `CloseablePath` constructor but validate in the `getPathOrFile` method.
> 
> If the `CloseablePath` constructor throws an exception, it would be handled similarly to #3911, i.e., with a try/catch that ensures the underlying factory is also closed in case a `PreconditionViolationException` is thrown by the temp directory validation. This way, no `CloseablePath` instance would be created, and no close handling would need to be in the `getPathOrFile` caller.

Shouldn't we also delete the `Path` returned from `TempDirFactory.createTempDirectory` if it did not throw an exception before closing the factory? In most cases, the latter should take care of the former but that's not necessarily the case.

> Of course, we can push this logic up to `getPathOrFile` and that will require explicit closure of the `CloseablePath`, as you mentioned.
> 
> I think both directions can work so happy to follow your preference. I just wanted to bring both options to the table üôÇ

I'll leave the decision where to put the check up to you.

> Shouldn't we also delete the `Path` returned from `TempDirFactory.createTempDirectory` if it did not throw an exception before closing the factory? In most cases, the latter should take care of the former but that's not necessarily the case.

You're absolutely right ü§¶ let me revise that in #3911.

body: @scordio I'd like to include this in 5.11 which is scheduled for Wednesday. Do you have time to work on it in the next few days or should I take over?
Yes, I have time, I was waiting for #3920 üôÇ I should be able to submit something by the end of tomorrow
